title: What will be the closing price of Bitcoin on 8 June 2018, according to CNBC?
preds: Should have trusted my gut and gone more aggressive with the <$8000 trend.   BUT, if I would have been that confident; I would be a day trader.  :D

Yesterday the SEC Commissioner said that Bitcoins are not securities - so they won't be regulated as such but without that , confidence may not rebound for years if at all, I don't see a way back for virtual currencies.
Gotta love $BTC.  Gonna suck come Friday and it pops over 8k.
Popping up and down $100 in 7600-7700 range. Stoopid bitcoin, hate it.
At 7,700. Spiked up $200 in a minute, this thing is so not ready for mainstream before 2020 at the earliest. It is so rigged.

Very close to the census date, I am updating my previous estimate - price presently at 2,5% off the $8k barrier; volatility charts indicate high probability of upward move based on historical moves; speculative market very much alive.
Gradually getting up there from 7300 to 7400 to 7500 and 7600. Just not sure if it'll break 8k by 8th of June.
Crazy wild volatility in this market(66% past 30 days) makes it hard to zero in on this until the last minute.

Rockets 7100 to 7400. Hmm 0% chance it replaces the Fed.  The 1Y chart lags, great another bit of chaos to factor in. What if it does climb up over 8900 and on June 8th it goes over 9k (then everyone piles 100% in to 3rd box at last minute LOL) but according to the chart it's still at <9k? Nuts.
Like Jacks Magic Beans - rebounding today...

66 28 & 5% for <8, 8k & 9k.  A few more spikes up and we'll be back over 8. Come on BItty, don't let the gubmint grind you down, you can do it! Stats: 253 from only 85 of us here. Too many are predicting based on the past, seeing it go under 7500 and panicking. It'll come back up again (well if it doesn't then the bubble has well and truly finally popped as it goes down to be a niche $100/coin thing for nerds and preppers).
IMHO - the support level through Summer will be 7K

Bounced off 7300, so maybe it wasn't going down to 6k like bears thought. Can it get back up past 7850 mark and breach 8k? Who knows. Just 2 weeks to go.  Has dropped 11 to 7 in 2 weeks. For all we know it could get stupid and go back up to 11k in 2 weeks. SMH. Hate this market. But a fun q on here. Pity there is only 229 bets from 82 bettors.

WoC 61% <$8k. Guess the whales aren't going to buy-in again for their pump and dumps. Losing it's lustre? Is Ethereum the future?  Now 7.6k with 7k floor, so does it keep going down to there and then back up to 10k by August? Some HODLers said it'll be 50k soon LOL. John McAfee said he's cannabilise his own member if it doesn't get to $1mn by 2020 or so.  For Jun 8th Friday (2 weeks) it could go down to 7k and bounce back up to be 7.5 or go back up to 8.5k or even 9.2k. It is a crazy market that makes no sense. Up and down 10% in 5 days. Nuts. All up to what the whales conspire.  As Trumpy would say, 'totally rigged'.

Price has stabilized but there hasn't been a bullish correction suggesting a limited impetus for buying at these levels. Technically, today's candlestick hints at indecision in the market. Ergo I am increasing the <8k bin.

Historically bitcoin is an uptrend currency, it's been in an uptrend for the last 10 years. Also corrections are quite common, the last correction was in 2014 and it was the longest with 1 year bear market. Today correction to 5800 was pretty fast, once corrections are made usually it begins a slow bull trend, the trendline seems posing for a 9000 11,000 price for that date.
As time has passed and the price decreased somewhat since my prior forecast it looks less likely for bitcoin to make it to 10-11 or +11K range. Adjusting probabilities slightly to reflect that.

The Jig is Up - Regulators finally spotted trends that our very own identified last year - and I apologize - I can't recall which of us it was that found the spoof trading etc. THe trick here is missing the temporary price recovery from bargain hunters and victims who are watching price3s plunge this morning.

Now that the market has broken below the 8k support (and on good volume) this raises the chances the price will end up below 8k. I will be waiting to see if it bounces back right away (a not uncommon occurrence). If not, it raises the chances it will be stuck below 8 for longer.
Price has dropped considerably, at 7.5K currently, but it is generally volatile so adjusting to favor first bucket, less than 8K.

Adjusting forecast with 5% more in the Less than 8k bin and -5% in the Between $8,000 and $9,000, inclusive bin based on an interesting article I came across while trying to find a nice recent bitcoin exchange rate chart: https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-closing-on-long-term-bear-indicator-not-seen-since-2014/  "Following bitcoin's recent losses, a key long-term trend indicator is looking increasingly bearish. Notably, the five-month moving average (MA) has rolled over in favor of the bears and looks set to cut the 10-month MA from above - a bearish crossover that hasn't been seen since June 2014. If that occurs it could be a worrying signal for the long-term price outlook. Back then, following an identical crossover in June 2014, the cryptocurrency subsequently dropped by 70 percent (from $580 to $166) in the seven months leading up to January 2015. This time around, the bearish crossover will likely occur at the turn of the month, if bitcoin extends the current decline towards the $7,000 mark, and would open the doors for a deeper sell-off towards the $5,000 mark." Comments: I'm still putting 5% in the More than $9,000 but less than $10,000 bin because of bitcoins volatility but I expect that I will be decreasing that as the deadline approaches.
Although bitcoin is very volitile it seems to in a range between $6.5 and $11

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-crypto-currency-index/ethereum-is-top-public-blockchain-bitcoin-no-13-in-chinas-new-index-idUSKCN1II2R9
In this segment of the magical economy, nothing necessarily means anything, but shifting numbers around anyway.

Bitcoin dropped about 10 percent this week despite calls that it would rally on the back of major blockchain conference held in New York City.
Last year, bitcoin rallied 69 percent during the Consensus conference, according to Fundstrat.
"Many repeat attendees commented that the panels felt more like commercials than substantive discussions, which was not the case last year," says Fundstrat digital currency analyst Alex Kern.
Trailing 30 day vol is a crazy 58% with current price of 8073.
Updating for the latest price drop.

Current price down to $8340, revising forecast downward to reflect lower price. Still longer term bullish on BTC, but bearish short- to mid-term due to historic tendency for these bear runs to take a bit longer to play out. May be wrong of course. Preserving possibility of an upside break too, simply due to volatility of BTC overall -- with three weeks left, large movements in any direction remain possible.
Updating after the market failed to break back above the 50 and 200 moving averages and decisively broke below a support level around 8400.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bitcoin-hongkong-ipo/chinese-bitcoin-mining-gear-makers-set-sights-on-worlds-largest-bitcoin-ipos-idUSKCN1IG0F2?il=0 Two Chinese bitcoin mining equipment makers are set to test international investor appetite for cryptocurrencies with plans to raise as much as $1 billion each - in what are expected to be the world’s largest bitcoin-focused floats to date. "While the price of bitcoin BTC=BTSP has tumbled 35 percent this year and Beijing has tightened its grip on trade in the virtual currency, equipment makers are still hungry for capital to fund growth and to meet still robust demand for their machines. Both are seeking as much as $1 billion, IFR said, which would dwarf other known listings for crytopcurrency firms.
. . . 
[One of the companies], Canaan, estimates it supplies a quarter of the world’s bitcoin blockchain computing power, according to a Reuters interview last month with co-chairman Jianping Kong, who also expects China’s push to promote its domestic chip industry to help drive growth for the company. [The other company], Ebang, delisted from China’s National Equities Exchange and Quotations, also known as the New Third Board, this year after announcing in January that it would seek a Hong Kong listing. While many companies promote links to bitcoin and, more commonly, blockchain - the distributed ledger technology that underpins bitcoin - few that focus on the cryptocurrency have listed publicly.
. . . 
Credit Suisse, CMB International, Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley are joint sponsors for Canaan’s float, IFR added.
. . . 
Bitcoin mining equipment makers make computers with special chips that mine the coins more efficiently than more mainstream chips made by companies such as Intel.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The article doesn't say when this will happen, but markets may respond on just the news of the plan.  I'm assuming that this news will positively impact the price . . .  However, the current price is $8521, so I'm adjusting my forecast.
Over 10,000 would cause anxiety in investors because they fear a corresponding drop in prices would soon follow.
The trend for the past few weeks appears to be tracking within a narrow range with small rises and falls on a finer timescale but slightly increasing but I'm unfamiliar with longer term trends

Today is May 14, the price is 8,700. Looking at what I feel are the two comparable boom/bust cycles for Bitcoin it took about 5-12 months for the price to hit a bottom before recovering. That was June of 2011, peaking about 29.60, then bottoming about 2.2 in November, so about 90% lower about 5 months later. Next was December 2013, peaking about 1,100 then bottoming out about 80% lower about Jan 2014, so about a year later.  We are currently about 5 months from the peak, and have seen about a 60% loss in value. As the previous bottoms were still lower, I am inclined to think that we are overall more likely to see a further price decline in the future. However, this is ameliorated by the fact that the 2014 crash was more moderate than the 2011 crash. This is consistent with the overall lowering of volatility in BTC since its inception. So I would lean slightly toward a lower price bottom, but not too hard. Perhaps about 60% below today's price by June 8, and 40% at or above today's price, with the probabilities clustering near today's price. I think that the market overall is very uncertain as the biggest basic risk to BTC and crypto is based around government regulation, particularly in the West -- OECD countries - but some of the other major economies too. If they move to stifle innovation as it would limit their ability to manage the money supply, that will hurt BTC in the near to mid-term, and I am unsure what would happen in the longer term -- the value of the tech might be so strong that it overcomes entrenched interests like banking and national governments to become adopted anyway in the long-term. Or it may become a default black market currency mostly limited to the developing world, where people are more motivated to defy government restrictions to protect their assets from government corruption/ rampant inflation.  Until June 8, those factors won't be overly relevant.
Bitcoin has found a strong price channel it is unlikely to break out of in the very near term.

I think Bitcoin is generally overpriced, but it could easily reach above 20K if people get excited and have cash to burn. That said, I'm going to assume near term stability and go with a purely unscientific gut instinct target favoring 10K to 11K for now.

@Emil @ https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/733317  has done some incredible number crunching.   If I understand correctly what his latest numbers mean, based on the pattern of the closing value of Bitcoins since 2/8, 
-the mean of the 30 day rolling change was -2%, which works out to $9109
-25% of the time the change was a loss greater than -22%, which works out to $7250
-25% of the time the change was a gain greater than +13%, which works out to $10,469
-100% of the time the change was a loss that was less than -41%, which works out to $5484
-100% of the time the change was a gain that was less than +45%, which works out to $13,478 So, assuming the same degree of volatility as there's been since February.
0% of my forecast should be below $5,484
25% should be between $5,484 and $7250
50% should be  between $7250 and 10,469
25% should be between $10,469 and $13,478
0% should be above $13,478 How to parcel out those stats into the bins we have???
What do I make of the fact that it was $8737 when I just checked it??? All of the above ignores politics and market forces.  Things which would depress the price of Bitcoin:  
-RSK crackdown on Bitcoin exchanges Things which might increase the attractiveness of Bitcoin:
-the US pulling out of JCPOA and the subsequent increase in the price of oil and fear of the imposition of sanctions again (you can bet that wealthy Iranians are pulling out of US assets as fast as they can while they still can and that money has to go somewhere
-continued capital flight out of Venezuela (what little that's still left there!), China & Russia as Xi & Putin tighten their grips on their respective countries
-capital flight out of KSA in anticipation of war???
-capital flight out of the UK in anticipation of a further weakening of the pound???
-if DJT pulls the US out of NAFTA, what will that do to the US dollar, Canadian dollar and Mexican peso??  Will citizens of all 3 countries turn to Bitcoin to cushion currency fluctuations? I'm weighting the $8-9k bin higher than Emil's stats suggest because it seems that Bitcoin may end up on the down side of $9109 since that's where it currently is, but I'll be checking this every day!!!

closing price on 5/9 was $9295.00
It is currently $8685 If the next 30 days are "average" that would put the closing price on 6/9 @ $10,875, based on Emil's calculation of an average change of +17% per month over the last 2 yrs. If the 30 days after 5/9 follow the pattern of the previous 30 days, then on 6/9 the closing price will be $12,756 If we start with the price today of $8685, then in 30 days it will be $10,161, based on Emil's 17% per month increase. I hate forecasting against today's reality, even though Bitcoin is very volatile and forecasting is about change.   There's a 50% probability according to Emil that the increase will be between +31% and +2%. If it increased 3.6% from today it would be just under $9k Shifting forecast:  reducing below $8k, increasing $9-10k.
Bitcoin is under pressure because of police investigations in South Korea. Nvidia told its scepticism about bitcoins in general.

After taking account of BTC's speculative nature, and having allowed for the "corrective" effect of futures markets, the positive uncertainty surrounding technological affordances of blockchain (the underlying technology) drives my prediction for a 8-10k band with preference to the 9k+ band. The Gaussian distribution in my prediction (thin-tailed) reflects the short prediction window - a longer term prediction would come with much fatter tails due to the aforementioned uncertainty.

The price is between 8k and 9k currently and it has a good chance of staying there. However I think bitcoin price is purely driven by speculation and therefore in the long run it is more likely to go down than up. But I do not know when that "long run" is. Nevertheless I am putting higher probability on 0-8000 range because: (a) the range is wide (b) Asset prices tend to move down faster than they go up.

News today that Facebook is looking into issuing its own cryptocurrency.  Also today, cryptocurrencies declined by more than $50 billion over the past 24 hours.  Bitcoin price down 8% to 
$8,500 after police raided headquarters of major South Korean exchange and the selloff of 8,000 bitcoin by Mt. Gox trustee.
I approach this as a set of unknown unknowns and bet it like the daily double.

As of this writing, 5/9/18, Bitcoin has ranged in the 9100 to 9900 range. This has been happening or the last 3 weeks. 9000 seems to be a base. 10,000 seems to be a ceiling. I don't see any forces to push it down. Breaking through the 10,000 barrier is tough because everyone takes the summer off, depending on which part of the world you live in. Point is, I think there will not be a lot of activity to push it above 10,000 without some other outside event that cannot be seen as of this writing.

Just announced today, billionaire Mike Novogratz and Bloomberg LP are teaming up to launch the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index (BGCI), which will track the aggregate performance of a basket of large-cap cryptocurrencies.  “The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index brings unprecedented transparency to the crypto markets. We are excited to help drive the decentralized revolution forward through the creation of BGCI.” https://www.ccn.com/bloomberg-inks-deal-with-novogratz-founded-galaxy-digital-to-launch-cryptocurrency-price-index/ Now that cryptocurrencies are getting more mainstream, is the price expected to be less volatile?  Is it expected to rise or lower?  Novogratz, a former hedge fund manager at Fortress Investment Group, recently raised $250 million to create a “cryptocurrency merchant bank” that will be publicly-listed in Canada. Today's price: $9,333.04 (Low $8,983.76; High $9,389.45; Marketcap $158.89B)

Volatility is enormous when it comes to BTC, so a good general (outside view) heuristic is to have a spread out probability distribution.  When it comes to prices at this specific moment in time, these are some considerations that are important (they are my opinions) 1) BTC is still in a bubble. It is hard to come up with reasonable assumptions (e.g. some belief about what % of monetary demand BTC will come to represent in the future and how that should be discounted to the present) that justify its current price level.  2) Regardless of 1), market psychology has been a supportive element for the price. Despite the recent downturn, we have seen price support repeatedly at the 6-7k levels. The bubble might not be ready to burst just yet. We are seeing sentiment improve in the market. There are fewer news stories about regulatory backlash. The problems around Tether have quieted down. Finally, the fact that the price has stabilized should diffuse the amount of fear doubt and uncertainty in the market (circular logic here, but that is the nature of markets to some degree isn't it) 3) the price is likely to receive substantial support around the 9k level. There is currently a convergence in that vicinity of the 50, 100 and 200 day moving averages. This is in addition to the support we have already seen at the 6-7k levels, which should limit the downside.  4) There have been some positive stories lately about Goldman Sachs and ICE wanting to open trading, which signals institutional buy-in and potential demand (ICE trading in particular might involve physical ownership of BTC). There is also the diffusion of the lightning network which should boost the use case for BTC. 5) Alt-coins in some sense compete with BTC for crypto investor demand. There are some signs we might be entering an alt-coin cycle where more money will flow toward those.
Going with somewhat of an even spread to start. On April 9, Bitcoin was valued at $6,772 at close. One month later (today) it's over $9,000. Obviously, there's some volatility...
